Executive Summary



Well known for their ability to engineer products to suit unique customer applications, Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility specialists solve problems for the demanding nuclear, semiconductor and hazardous materials industries. With the largest boron isotope enrichment facility in the world, Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility continues to be the leading manufacturer of enriched boron.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 

Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility is committed to the protection of the safety, health and environment of all individuals affected by our business activities, including employees, visitors, contractors, customers and the communities in which we operate.  The safety and health of employees is our primary concern and first priority. All injuries, occupational illnesses, and environmental incidents can be prevented, and an incident-free environment is achievable. This commitment is outlined in Boron's EHS Policy.



Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility and RMP Regulated Substances 

Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility purchases and utilizes boron trifluoride (BF3) as a raw material feedstock into its boron isotopic separation process.   Boron trifluoride is delivered to the site as a compressed gas in tube trailers consisting of 6 individual tubes, containing 3500 pounds of BF3 gas at a pressure of 1800 psig.  The BF3 gas is transferred from a single tube of the tube trailer into the production area; tubes are used sequentially.  Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility sells isotopically enriched boron trifluoride into global semiconductor markets. Final product gas is stored and transported in portable compressed gas cylinders packaged in accordance with USDOT Hazardous Materials regulations. 

Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility maximum BF3 inventory storage, consisting of one to two tube trailers, BF3 contained in-process equipment, and final product BF3 inventory for sale, does not exceed 50,000 pounds. 



Accidental Release Prevention Prog

ram and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility boron trifluoride process area is considered a "covered process" under  OSHA's Process Management (PSM).  Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility has a fourteen element PSM program that includes process hazard analysis, operating procedures and safe work practices, training, emergency response, incident and "near miss" investigation and contractor management.  Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility PSM Audit program is designed to ensure continuous improvement of Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility PSM program.    Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility process improvement initiatives include prevention focused maintenance and equipment reliability improvements focuses on 100% prevention of chemical spills and releases. 



The Five-Year Accident History

Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility has had no RMP reportable "accidents" in the last 5 years.  All incidents and "near misses" that occur at the Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility are promptly contained, investigated and corrected to prevent recurrence. 



The Emergency Response Program

Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility has developed, and maintains, a working relationship with local emergency responders and the Local Emergency Response Coordinator to ensure openness of communication of the hazards associated with the Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility and appropriate emergency response procedures in the event of an emergency. 

In order to ensure compliance with all emergency response regulatory requirements, Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility is committed to continual improvement of it's Crisis Management Plan (CMP).  Key elements of Ceradyne Inc. Quapaw Facility CMP include emergency recognition, emergency action (including but not limited to containment, mitigation, public communication), training, drills and incorporating "lessons learned" into the continuous improvement of the CMP.  All facility personnel are trained in the hazardous chemical awareness and emergency response (evacuation) proce

dures. Individuals who respond to an emergency or to manage an incident scene, are trained as required to comply with Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) and related regulations.
